responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Improper input validation in github-issues-to-changelog.pl could allow command injection 
    analysis: |
      The github-issues-to-changelog.pl script takes user input from stdin without any validation or sanitization before using it in shell commands with backticks. This allows an attacker to inject arbitrary shell commands by providing malicious input containing backticks and shell metacharacters.

      For example, if an attacker provides the following input:
      `foo; rm -rf /; echo `
      It would result in executing the injected rm -rf / command.

      This flaw could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary commands on the system running the script, potentially allowing full compromise of the system.
    cwe: CWE-78
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - github-issues-to-changelog.pl
    classification: very promising

  - headline: Improper input validation in checklang.pl could allow file inclusion vulnerabilities
    analysis: |
      The checklang.pl script takes a list of languages and attempts to open and parse the associated language include file. However, the language name is not properly validated before being used to construct the filename.

      This could allow an attacker to provide special characters or inject relative paths using directory traversal (../) to access files outside of the intended lang directory.

      For example, an attacker could provide a language value like:
      ../../../../etc/passwd%00
      
      This would result in the script attempting to access the /etc/passwd file on the system. This could potentially allow reading of sensitive files.
    cwe: CWE-22
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - checklang.pl
    classification: very promising
    
  - headline: makedist.sh script allows anyone to create directories and overwrite files in parent directory
    analysis: |  
      The makedist.sh script unsafely copies files from its own directory one level up to a "dist" directory it creates there using the script-provided name. It uses relative paths like "../" to refer to the parent directory.
      
      However, there is no validation on the user-provided $NAME parameter which is used to construct the destination directory. This allows an attacker to provide a malicious name containing special characters, spaces, or even leading with "../" to refer to other parts of the filesystem.
      
      For example, providing a $NAME of "foo ../bar" would result in creating a "bar" directory and copying files there instead of to the intended "foo" directory.

      This flaw could allow overwriting unintended files on the filesystem, including sensitive data or critical system files.
    cwe: CWE-427
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - packaging/makedist.sh  
    classification: very promising
```

leads.headline: Improper input validation in github-issues-to-changelog.pl could allow command injection
leads.analysis:
The github-issues-to-changelog.pl script takes user input from stdin without any validation or sanitization before using it in shell commands with backticks. This allows an attacker to inject arbitrary shell commands by providing malicious input containing backticks and shell metacharacters.

For example, if an attacker provides the following input:
foo; rm -rf /; echo 
It would result in executing the injected rm -rf / command.

This flaw could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary commands on the system running the script, potentially allowing full compromise of the system.

leads.headline: Improper input validation in checklang.pl could allow file inclusion vulnerabilities
leads.analysis:
The checklang.pl script takes a list of languages and attempts to open and parse the associated language include file. However, the language name is not properly validated before being used to construct the filename.

This could allow an attacker to provide special characters or inject relative paths using directory traversal (../) to access files outside of the intended lang directory.

For example, an attacker could provide a language value like:
../../../../etc/passwd%00

This would result in the script attempting to access the /etc/passwd file on the system. This could potentially allow reading of sensitive files.

leads.headline: makedist.sh script allows anyone to create directories and overwrite files in parent directory
leads.analysis:
The makedist.sh script unsafely copies files from its own directory one level up to a "dist" directory it creates there using the script-provided name. It uses relative paths like "../" to refer to the parent directory.

However, there is no validation on the user-provided $NAME parameter which is used to construct the destination directory. This allows an attacker to provide a malicious name containing special characters, spaces, or even leading with "../" to refer to other parts of the filesystem.

For example, providing a $NAME of "foo ../bar" would result in creating a "bar" directory and copying files there instead of to the intended "foo" directory.

This flaw could allow overwriting unintended files on the filesystem, including sensitive data or critical system files.
